entries.title: Joy fills Humboldt Park during ‘Benito Bowl’ halftime show watch party: 'It’s a good day to be Puerto Rican'
entries.summary: <p>Some fans were settling in to watch the Seattle Seahawks play the New England Patriots, but others were tuning in to see Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny take the Super Bowl stage for the halftime show.</p><p>Bad Bunny headlined Sunday’s performance, which some fans dubbed the “Benito Bowl.” The 31-year-old, born Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, is the first Spanish-language solo artist to headline a halftime show.</p><p>In Humboldt Park, Chicago’s largest Puerto Rican neighborhood, organizers of the annual Fiestas Puertorriqueñas hosted a watch party at their VIP Residencia pop-up space at 2701 W. Division St.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ff0000" name="image-ff0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dcfb2de/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/65501c2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4486c40/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="An inflatable tropical-themed facade covers the entrance to VIP Residencia Bar & Lounge in Humboldt Park for the "Benito Bowl" watch party. The event, held during the NFL championship on Sunday, Feb. 8, 2026, transformed the local venue into a Caribbean-inspired fan zone." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4486c40/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7de38fa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4486c40/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6048x3394+0+319/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F43%2Fd4%2Fe547d1aa449db78cc7cfb816e4b5%2Fbenitobowl-260208-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>An inflatable tropical-themed facade decorates the entrance to VIP Residencia Bar & Lounge in Humboldt Park for the “Benito Bowl” watch party. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The event drew dozens who cheered for the singer and sang along to his top reggaeton hits throughout the 13-minute performance. Instead of wearing their favorite team’s jersey, partygoers wore Puerto Rican flags, Bad Bunny T-shirts and <i>pavas</i>, traditional Puerto Rican straw hats.</p><p>Organizer Melissa Gomez said she wanted to create an event that would bring the community together, and Bad Bunny’s performance provided the perfect occasion to do just that.</p><p>“Bad Bunny always has shown his love for his community. For Puerto Ricans and for all Latinos,” Gomez said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Football fans and fans of Puerto Rican super star Bad Bunny crowd the VIP Residencia Bar & Lounge in Humboldt Park, some wore traditional straw hats.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>That message came through during his performance, which featured men, women and children on a set reminiscent of Puerto Rico. He closed the show with a parade of flags from countries representing North, Central and South America, ending with the message “Together, we are America.”</p><p>The performance also included cameos from Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin.</p><p>“I’m feeling really so proud,” said Evelyn Cato, 60, of Logan Square. “Despite all of the negativity, he’s brought communities together.”</p><p>Bad Bunny’s performance drew both anticipation and controversy. Many fans were eager to see him headline the show, but it also sparked backlash from conservatives. The singer has been an outspoken critic of President Donald Trump's immigration policies and recently spoke out, saying "ICE out" during his recent Grammy Awards acceptance speech.</p><p>Trump posted on social media that the performance was “absolutely terrible, one of the worst, EVER!”</p><p>Turning Point USA, the organization founded by Charlie Kirk, organized an alternative, "All-American" halftime show that was promoted by Vice President J.D. Vance and featured headliner Kid Rock.</p><p>Gomez said there was “no better choice” for a halftime performer than Bad Bunny, who has been Spotify's top-streaming artist for four of the last six years.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-c60000" name="image-c60000"></a> <picture class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A Bad Bunny cutout and large screens fill the VIP Residencia Bar & Lounge in Humboldt Park, where fans gathered for the Super Bowl halftime show, which featured Bad Bunny, Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“I've always loved watching the performances, no matter who it is,” she said. “The Super Bowl halftime has always been the top-charting artist at the time, and that's Benito right now.”</p><p>Bad Bunny first appeared on the Super Bowl stage during the 2020 halftime show, when he joined headliners Shakira and Jennifer Lopez as a guest performer.</p><p>Erika Latines, 49, who showed up at the party in her favorite Bad Bunny T-shirt, said the singer is one of the few artists who uses their platform to speak out against injustice.</p><p>“His messages are not just for Latinos, it’s for humanity,” Latines said.</p><p>Latines, who lives on the South Side, said Chicago “needed” to be able to gather and celebrate after several neighborhoods were recently targeted by Trump’s aggressive deportation campaign that saw hundreds of federal agents fanning out across neighborhoods, stoking fear.</p><p>“The Super Bowl brings us together, not because of the NFL, but because of who we are as a community,” she said.</p><p>Ald. Jessie Fuentes (26th) was among the crowd and said she joined to show support for a small business and pride for her Puerto Rican heritage.</p><p>“It’s a good day to be Puerto Rican,” she said.</p><p>Fuentes also added it was important for Latino communities to share in joy after communities across the country have been “terrorized” by the Trump administration.</p><p>“It’s an exciting day to resist and to show the world that Latinos belong here,” she said.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" entries.title: Super Bowl LX: Seahawks defense rocks Patriots for 29-13 win, lurks as challenge for Bears next season
entries.summary: <p>SANTA CLARA, Calif. — If the Bears and quarterback Caleb Williams are able to step into being a contender next season, the Seahawks’ defense will be waiting for them. After what they did throughout the season and in Super Bowl LX on Sunday, that’s going to be daunting for everyone in the NFL.</p><p>The Seahawks shut down the Patriots at nearly every turn to win 29-13 and capture their second championship and avenge the Legion of Boom’s brutal loss to Tom Brady 11 years ago.</p><p>They threatened to deliver the first shutout in Super Bowl history, holding the Patriots scoreless until a lapse early in the fourth quarter, before allowing two late touchdowns.</p><p>Seahawks coach Mike Macdonald’s defense ran the show.</p><p>They essentially sealed the game when safety Julian Love, who grew up in Logan Square and played at Nazareth Academy, intercepted a pass that Patriots quarterback Drake Maye sailed over the middle of the field as he desperately tried to give the Patriots a chance.</p><p>Love intercepted the ball with 8:37 remaining and returned it 35 yards into Patriots territory to set up another score and give the Seahawks a commanding 22-7 lead.</p><p>The Seahawks followed that with another takeaway when cornerback Devon Witherspoon, from University of Illinois, hit Maye as he threw, and the ball deflected to linebacker Uchenna Nwosu in the backfield. Nwosu had a clear path to the end zone for a 45-yard touchdown return.</p><p>The game didn’t have the star power or thrills of recent Super Bowls, but the Seahawks don’t care. Everyone can call it boring while they party in the Bay Area and start designing championship rings.</p><p>The legends of the Seahawks’ previous era couldn’t help but love this defense. After allowing the fewest points in the league during the regular season, the Seahawks forced the Patriots to punt on their first eight possessions and didn’t let them cross the Seattle 40-yard line until Maye’s 24-yard pass to Mack Hollins with 12:35 remaining.</p><p>Their defensive line continued to be one of the most overwhelming forces in the NFL, pressuring Maye throughout the game and holding him to 27-for-43 passing for 295 yards with two touchdowns and two interceptions.</p><p>The Seahawks sacked him six times and forced him into three turnovers.</p><p>The only reason the Patriots didn’t punt a ninth consecutive time to open the game was because Seahawks pass rusher Derick Hall sacked Maye on a third-and-five near midfield, and defensive tackle Byron Murphy II recovered it at the Patriots’ 37-yard line with 10 seconds left in the third quarter.</p><p>It was devastating for a Patriots team that couldn’t get anything going.</p><p>The Seahawks turned that into a 16-yard touchdown pass from Sam Darnold to tight end AJ Barner for a 19-0 lead.</p><p>Maye answered with the pass to Hollins, the Patriots’ longest play of the game, and went back to him for a 35-yard touchdown pass on the next play, but it was too late for a rally at that point.</p><p>Throughout the Bears’ rebuild under general manager Ryan Poles the last four seasons, the challenge has been not only to solve all of their problems, but to outrace teams around the league that are trying to do the same. Rebuilding is a zero-sum competition.</p><p>The Seahawks went 25-26 over the 2021 through ’23 seasons before resetting with the hire McDonald in ’24 and signing Darnold going into this season. Rebuild complete, no question.</p><p>The same can be said of the Patriots despite the loss. They were in worse shape than the Bears after back-to-back 4-13 seasons in 2023 and ’24, but like the Bears, found their answer in a capable coach in Mike Vrabel and a competent offensive strategist in coordinator Josh McDaniels.</p><p>That led to a breakout season for Maye, who leapfrogged Williams, the Commanders’ Jayden Daniels and the Broncos’ Bo Nix in the ongoing quarterback battle of the 2024 draft class by leading the league with a 113.5 passer rating, finishing second in the MVP voting and becoming the first from that group to reach a Super Bowl.</p><p>Seeing how well the Seahawks played is a reminder to the Bears that as exciting as their season was, their next step forward will be even hard. They’ve made progress, but there’s a lot to catch up to around the league, and this could be a tough opponent to get past for years.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Kyle Williams' Super 25 high school girls basketball rankings for Feb. 8, 2026
entries.summary: <p>Downers Grove North junior guard Campbell Thulin is always moving.</p><p>She regularly flies around the court searching for deflections, rebounds or trying to make herself available for her teammates to pass to. As soon as the ball leaves her fingertips, she darts toward the basket to try and get an offensive rebound if she knows it's off. Her relentless motor sets the tone for a Trojans team that, at 26-2, is enjoying one of the best seasons in program history.</p><p>After beating Hinsdale Central 48-32 on Friday, Downers Grove North clinched the West Suburban Conference Silver championship. Thulin scored a game-high 18 points. Senior guard Ady Fanta added 12 points and five rebounds, and freshman guard Eva Yerkovich scored seven points.</p><p>"It's really important to us," Thulin said of winning the conference. "It's a tribute to how hard we work. This [win] just gets us even more motivated for playoffs and to be ready to play like that."</p><p>The Trojans have won 12 straight games and are clicking at the right time.</p><p>"I like where we're at," Trojans coach Stephan Bolt said. " Defensively, we're tough and communicative. Offensively, we're starting to make some shots. We're seeing some things. We're executing what we're trying to execute, and it's fun to see them doing that, and it only gives them more confidence, which is, it's the right time to be doing that."</p><p>One of the keys for the Trojans is their stifling defense. They're absolutely suffocating and might be the best defense in the area. If a player gets beat off the dribble, there's a Trojan ready in help position.</p><p>When the Trojans are guarding drives, everyone does a good job of digging down, trying to dislodge the ball and create a deflection.The team has a freneticism on defense.</p><p>"It's our energy," Thulin said. "We play music on the bus. We bring the speaker [into] the locker room. It's kind of like a fun environment. We don't let the energy go down. We have to carry it [throughout the game]. Our coaches do a really good job with the stuff you do for practice. They give us good practice plans, and all we got to do is do what they're telling us to do."</p><p><b>Milestone moments</b></p><p>• Carmel freshman forward Liv Johnson is the best freshman in the state, and that might be underselling her. In Saturday's win against Benet, Johnson set the single-game scoring record after a 39-point performance. It's rare to see a freshman with her mix of shooting, basketball IQ and physicality. Johnson has already received offers from Illinois, Iowa, DePaul, Ohio State and Oklahoma. She's going to be fun to watch during the playoffs.</p><p>• Loyola senior guards Marycait Mackie and Clare Weasler became the winningest players in program history (127 wins). Mackie and Weasler are critical to Loyola's success because of their willingness to rebound, defend, and sacrifice individual numbers for team success.</p><p>• Maine East guard Arabella Silva scored a career-high 46 points in a win over Niles West. She's already surpassed 2,000 points as a junior.</p><p><b>The Super 25, with record and last week’s ranking:</b></p><p><b>1. Nazareth (25-3) 1</b></p><p>Beat Marist</p><p><b>2. entries.title: Chicago Tribune owner Alden wants to acquire publisher of northwest suburban Daily Herald
entries.summary: <p>The investment fund that owns the Chicago Tribune wants to acquire the suburban Daily Herald newspaper but could be in for a fight.</p><p>Alden Global Capital, aggressive as a buyer and cost-cutter at American newspapers, declared its desire for the Daily Herald via a full-page ad in Sunday’s Tribune. The Herald, long a dominant source of northwest suburban news, has shared the misfortune of traditional media outlets struggling to keep an audience and advertisers in the digital age.</p><p>The ad was a statement from the Tribune itself addressed to shareholders of Paddock Publications, which owns the Herald. It said, “We, at the Chicago Tribune, can pay the highest price to acquire Paddock, 30% more than anyone else. We can also offer the best employment terms for Paddock’s employees.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The <a href="https://twitter.com/chicagotribune?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@chicagotribune</a> wants to buy the Daily Herald <a href="https://t.co/ngZlceTvQw">pic.twitter.com/ngZlceTvQw</a></p>— Gregory Royal Pratt (@royalpratt) <a href="https://twitter.com/royalpratt/status/2020496799518306428?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 8, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>In January, Paddock filed a notice with the state that it is considering a sale. The notice included no details, and the company has issued none since then.</p><p>Current and former media people familiar with the Herald speculated privately that the company could be sold to Crystal Lake-based Shaw Media, which owns newspapers and radio stations across northern Illinois and Iowa. Its papers, some just outside Daily Herald territory, include the Northwest Herald in Crystal Lake, the Kane County Chronicle and the Herald-News in Joliet.</p><p>Publicists and executives at Alden, Shaw and Paddock did not return messages Sunday.</p><p>The Alden-Tribune pitch acknowledged Paddock’s unusual situation. It’s an employee-owned company and to support a bid from Alden, workers might want assurances about job security.</p><p>Alden, however, is known for ruthless cost-cutting at its more than 200 daily and weekly newspapers. At the Tribune, it has reduced staff via several rounds of buyouts and layoffs since it took over in 2021.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/07/24/chicago-tribune-newsroom-layoffs-alden-global-capital" >Chicago Tribune lays off 8 from newsroom, including 5 union members</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/business/2021/2/16/22286555/tribune-publishing-sells-to-alden-global-capital" >Tribune Publishing sells to Alden Global Capital</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>In 2023, Alden bought the Daily Herald’s printing plant in Schaumburg to keep producing the Tribune and serve the Sun-Times, Herald and other customers. The deal was needed because Alden sold the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/5/5/23712729/ballys-casino-chicago-goose-island-freedom-center-tribune" >former Tribune printing plant in 2022 </a>for $200 million. The former printing plant has been demolished to make way for a Bally’s casino.</p><p>Alden’s reputation worked against it last year when shareholders refused to sell it the Dallas Morning News, preferring instead a lower offer from Hearst. In 2022, Alden was thwarted in its bid for Lee Enterprises, publisher of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and other papers.<br></p>

entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: Super Bowl LX: Seahawks MVP Kenneth Walker III powers offense to win Super Bowl MVP
entries.summary: <p>SANTA CLARA, Calif. — The Seahawks went back to a different era in their <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/08/super-bowl-lx-seahawks-lead-patriots-9-0-at-halftime-as-defenses-dominate" >29-13 victory</a> over the Patriots in Super Bowl LX on Sunday. It was all about their defense and ground game.</p><p>Running back <b>Kenneth Walker III</b> wasn’t spectacular, but he was steady as he rolled up 135 yards on 27 carries and claimed MVP honors. That tied <b>Thurman Thomas</b> for eighth-most in a Super Bowl. Walker also caught two passes for 26 yards.</p><p>Walker nearly put himself among the all-time rushing performances with what would’ve been a 49-yard run late in the game, but that play was waved off because of a holding penalty.</p><p>The Seahawks needed Walker to carry the load in the playoffs after they lost running back <b>Zach Charbonnet</b> to a torn anterior cruciate ligament in the divisional round, and he did. In their postseason victories over the 49ers, Rams and Patriots, Walker totaled 313 yards and four touchdowns.</p><p>Among the Seahawks’ running backs, Walker took all but two carries.</p><p>“That was incredible,” wide receiver <b>Cooper Kupp</b> said. “Him and Zach Charbonnet were an unbelievable 1-2 punch. For [Walker] to just shoulder the load and step up his game to another level, I was so proud of him. He’s so well-deserving of that.”</p><p>The Seahawks’ passing game struggled as <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/06/ridiculed-and-doubted-for-years-seahawks-qb-sam-darnold-declines-to-gloat-at-super-bowl-lx" >quarterback <b>Sam Darnold</b></a> opened the game 6-for-17 before leveling out to finish 19-for-38 for 202 yards with a touchdown, but Walker got them moving enough to take an early lead. He had their two longest plays with runs of 29 and 30 yards in the second quarter as they took a 9-0 lead at halftime.</p><h3>Urlacher endorses Williams</h3><p>Few would be more qualified to make such a declaration, so it meant something when Hall of Fame linebacker <b>Brian Urlacher</b> certified Bears quarterback <b>Caleb Williams</b> as “a badass.”</p><p>Urlacher delighted in watching Williams propel the Bears to an NFC North title and a playoff victory, calling him “frickin’ phenomenal” ahead of Super Bowl LX, and believes the team found its franchise quarterback.</p><p>“He’s a badass,” Urlacher told the Sun-Times. “When things go bad, he’s at his best. When [stuff] breaks down, that dude shows up. He can make every throw, just like he said.</p><p>“I was just so impressed. Unbelievable, and I’m so excited for the future. He could be there the next 20 years. He should be.”</p><h3>Falcons split with Pace</h3><p>New management for the Falcons meant the ouster of former Bears general manager <b>Ryan Pace</b>. He was vice president of football operations and was fired by new president of football <b>Matt Ryan</b> and GM <b>Ian Cunningham</b>, NFL Network reported.</p><p>Pace, 48, got his first shot at being a general manager when the Bears hired him in 2015 after a long run as a Saints scout and executive. Both of his coaching hires, <b>John Fox</b> and <b>Matt Nagy</b>, were fired in four seasons or fewer. Both of his first-round picks at quarterback, <b>Mitch Trubisky</b> and <b>Justin Fields</b>, failed to establish themselves and earn a second contract with the team.</p><p>The Bears went 48-65 with two playoff appearances under Pace (one for going 8-8 in 2020), and he left them in shambles when they fired him after the 2021 season. The only players left on the roster from the Pace era are tight end <b>Cole Kmet</b>, kicker <b>Cairo Santos</b> and cornerback <b>Jaylon Johnson</b>.</p><h3>Mills sacks Maye</h3><p>Seahawks defensive tackle <b>Rylie Mills</b>, a rookie who played at Lake Forest High School and Notre Dame, picked a tremendous time for his first NFL sack.</p><p>He dropped Patriots quarterback <b>Drake Maye</b> for a 10-yard loss in the second quarter as part of a sequence in which the Seahawks forced a punt after taking a 6-0 lead.</p><p>Mills was a fifth-round pick after tearing his ACL in the playoffs during his senior season with the Irish.</p><h3>See you soon</h3><p>The Bears are one of five teams that will face both Super Bowl LX participants next season. They will host the Patriots for the second time in three seasons and visit the Seahawks for the first time since 2021.</p><p>The last time the Bears played both Super Bowl teams from the previous season was in 2018, when they lost to the Patriots in the regular season and fell to the Eagles in the playoffs. The four AFC West teams also will face the Seahawks and Patriots next season, plus there will be a Super Bowl rematch in Seattle.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Trump's propaganda machine revs up, thanks to power of video
entries.summary: <p>Over a century ago, anarchists embraced the idea of “propaganda of the deed.” This idea was rooted in the belief that dramatic political actions, often violent ones like assassinations, could spur the masses, instilling a spirit of revolt merely by being spectacular enough that they would command attention.</p><p>The acts themselves were seen as the message. Simply put, the idea was a form of political theater, performance in service of an ideology.</p><p>New York Times Opinion columnist Ezra Klein, in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/10/opinion/ezra-klein-podcast-m-gessen.html?unlocked_article_code=1.J1A.XogK.EH5cnm4Yk92h&smid=url-share" target="_blank" >January podcast</a>, asserted that we are currently seeing a resurrection of the early 20th century anarchistic idea but with a twist. The Trump administration, he says, even though not an anarchist collective but the state itself, “often operates through propaganda of the deed.”</p><p>American presidential administrations are no strangers to using performance in the service of an ideology. We can look back to the <a class="Link" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Works-Progress-Administration" target="_blank" >Works Progress Administration</a> of the 1930s, when the government funded actual performances, plays, concerts and traveling shows to promote the New Deal and inspire the masses.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-6f0000" name="module-6f0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Commentary bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Commentary</h2></div> </div><p>However, when we invoke the idea of “propaganda of the deed,” we are not referencing inspirational messaging. We are talking about a theater of shock and awe meant to stimulate nervous systems and open floodgates of adrenaline, all in service of an ideology.</p><p>With his alleged 2024 shooting of United Healthcare CEO Bryan Thompson, <a class="Link" href="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Luigi-Mangione" target="_blank" >Luigi Mangione </a>enacted propaganda of the deed in its purest early 20th century form, performing a spectacular and violent political action that would reverberate through the zeitgeist of popular culture. Perhaps he was motivated by a mythology surrounding any number of political assassinations. Ultimately, though, as history has shown time and again, the action does not lead to the intended outcome. Political violence by small actors rarely produces a future consistent with the goals of the deed.</p><h3>Violence performed by the state</h3><h3></h3><p>It is different, though, when the spectacle of violence, the propagation of the deed, is performed by the state.</p><p>Which brings us home to Chicago.</p><p>Who could forget the 1968 Democratic National Convention held here? The spectacle of state violence was broadcast into people’s living rooms across America when police beat protesters bloody in Grant Park. The spectacle was the message. The message was clear: Challenge the system, and this will happen to you. The goal was not only to suppress protest in the city but also to discipline those viewing the news footage at home.</p><p>Most recently, this state-sanctioned propaganda of the deed made itself apparent in the brutal and widely circulated shooting deaths of Renee Macklin Good and Alex Pretti by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis. Unlike the demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Convention, footage of this act was sent into our living rooms, reaching our eyes from a safe viewing distance, and it was directly in our faces, sent to our personal devices and shown multiple times, dissected from every angle imaginable.</p><p>In our new digital age, everything is performance because everyone is filming at all times. But the tables have turned. Citizen videography was once an effective tool for controlling the narrative and demanding accountability, as in the 1991 beating of Rodney King and the 2020 George Floyd murder, both perpetrated by police officers. Now it is being used to the advantage of the Trump administration.</p><p>This administration has perfected the art of taking a tool, the means by which activists have historically used to demand accountability, and manipulating it to serve their purposes. What was once video evidence of the violation of civil rights is now propaganda. What was once a powerful protective measure is now a warning. A far-reaching tool for citizen journalists gets turned into state media. And because this administration has no problem with spectacular acts of political violence, the message is clear: Challenge the system, and this will happen to you.</p><p>Propaganda of the deed, once an idea in pursuit of spurring a revolution, has become, in the digital age and at the hands of the current administration, an attempt at quelling one.</p><p><i>Janette DeFelice is a professional lecturer in health sciences at DePaul University and an author who writes about the intersection between medicine, politics and the stories we tell about who matters.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-910000" name="module-910000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Janette DeFelice

entries.title: Dear Abby: Husband gambles away retired couple's nest egg
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My husband developed an addiction to slot machines, but I didn't realize it. He would leave the house in the early morning before I woke up. Abby, he gambled away every single asset we had accumulated during our 58 years of marriage — somewhere around $600,000! I found out after he asked his grown children for "grocery money."</p><p>We are now bankrupt and must rely on our son, who offered to bail us out if he could be the trustee of our land, home, everything. He takes our monthly pensions and gives us a tiny allowance when we beg for something, but we are so poor we can't see a movie, eat out or go anywhere, including to visit our other kids.</p><p>I'm extremely depressed that nothing can solve this problem for the rest of my life. I'd find another job teaching, but I'm in my 80s and have limited mobility. At least I'm still in my home. I realize this is a dead-end street, but it helps to vent. Can you comment? — <i>LOST IT ALL IN TEXAS</i></p><p><b>DEAR LOST IT:</b> Is your son giving you such a tiny allowance because that is what your finances dictate, or is he trying to punish his father for getting into the predicament in which you find yourselves? Talk to your son and explain that the little money he doles out does not allow you to go anywhere, eat out or even see a movie, and see if you, his mother, can convince him to relent so you are not being punished for something you had no part in.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> I disagree with your response to "Dutiful Daughter in Alabama" (Nov. 10), who put a camera in her 80-year-old mom's den in case of a fall and overheard Mom make negative comments about her. Installing a camera in someone's home without their consent is disgusting and wrong, legally and morally. The elderly, in addition to the rest of the population, have a right to privacy in their own homes.</p><p>If "Dutiful Daughter" was really concerned about her mother falling, she should have considered a medical alert device, which would have notified family and summoned medical help the moment she fell. This is the safer, legal and common-sense solution.</p><p>It sounds like "Dutiful" had other undisclosed reasons for installing a camera. Why did she listen to a conversation that was clearly private? How would she know if her mother fell in another room of the house? If her mother was talking on the phone or visiting with her son, it should have been clear that she was OK and no additional spying was required.</p><p>After reading this letter, if children think it is OK to invade their parents' privacy without their consent, I'm happier than ever to be child-free. — <i>ANNE P. IN MINNESOTA</i></p><p><b>DEAR ANNE:</b> To put it mildly, you are not the only reader who disagreed with my answer to that letter. I confess, I didn't consider the privacy issues that were ignored. Mea culpa.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>To receive a collection of Abby's most memorable — and most frequently requested — poems and essays, send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby — Keepers Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: Playwright Tracy Letts on reviving ‘Bug’ on Broadway
entries.summary: <p>When Tracy Letts penned his play “Bug” 30 years ago, it seemed to come at a specific moment when conspiracy theories had become more integrated into mainstream society.</p><p>Letts, who would go on to win a Pulitzer Prize (for writing the play “August: Osage County”) and two Tony Awards (for acting and best play), said he grew up in a time when conspiracies were passed person-to-person “urban legend style.” Then, in the 1990s, as the internet became commercially accessible to households, the spread of information — and misinformation — changed.</p><div lives in New York. “So conspiracy theories have become much more mainstream in the intervening years since I wrote the play. And so, I thought, it seemed like time for revival.”</p><p>The critically acclaimed “Bug” is now playing at the Samuel J. Friedman Theatre on Broadway and reprises a staged version that appeared at Steppenwolf in 2021. The show features a lineup of Chicago theater vets, including Letts’s wife, Carrie Coon, plus Namir Smallwood and Randall Arney. The production is directed by Tony Award-winner David Cromer, a native of the Chicago area.</p><p>"Bug" is a chilling tale of paranoia, dissolution — and conspiracy. Coon and Smallwood play a couple isolated in an Oklahoma motel who slowly lose their grasp on reality. The role played by Smallwood was originated by, and written for, the Chicago-trained actor Michael Shannon, who also played the role in the film version opposite Ashley Judd.</p><div data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c4feec9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+140/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fd2%2F42%2F94c09c9f47e983368670c4883b2e%2Fcarrie-coon-and-namir-smallwood-in-steppenwolfs-production-of-bug-michael-brosilow-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The critically acclaimed “Bug,” with the original Steppenwolf casting of Carrie Coon (left) and Namir Smallwood, is now playing at the Samuel J. Friedman Theatre on Broadway.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Michael Brosilow</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Letts says the play is a love story with the couple experiencing shared psychosis.</p><p>“There's this psychological condition called ‘folie à deux’, the madness of two is the literal translation, in which we are able to pass delusion from one person to another person,” Letts said. “I came at it through the back end, in a sense, in that I was studying this issue of conspiracy theories and what makes people susceptible to a conspiracy theory. There's a real terror of conformity in our culture, and we will gladly believe somebody else's nonsense if it means we don't stick out from the group.”</p><p>In approaching these themes, Letts was careful not to judge his characters. “I didn't want to point at it in a way that was like, ‘Look at these freaks, look at these losers.’ What I wanted to do was try and find the thing about it that was identifiable to all of us,” he said.</p><p>That is how he arrived at making the play a love story. Two people, confined to a motel room, share a journey into conspiracy and delusion that slowly rips them apart. And it toys with the idea of what we can get other people to believe.</p><p>Even though the script was written more than 30 years ago, Letts said conspiracy theories are still prevalent in our society. Any psychological condition, he said, combined with our ability to pass “madness from person to person,” comes together to form a plot still relevant in a world where “people believe an election was stolen, or that people are murdering children in the basement of a pizza parlor for their blood.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-340000" name="image-340000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7e7a538/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/73de935/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7870a0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Playwright/Actor Tracy Letts poses for a photograph in the seats of the Steppenwolf Theatre in Chicago on Tuesday, March 22, 2016. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7870a0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f63f598/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7870a0a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+264/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F25%2Fb53d29aa425cb6dcb8cd5dc034c0%2Fletts-xxxx16-02.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“It’s very gratifying to write anything as a playwright and find that it has any value or currency for an audience many years later. So whenever you find that any of these pieces still speak to people, it’s great,” Letts said. Here, he’s pictured in 2016 at Steppenwolf Theatre.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tim Boyle/Sun-Times Media</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Outside of his 1996 play having its Broadway premiere, Letts has additional projects on the horizon. Later this month, in New York, the Circle in the Square Theatre School will stage a marathon festival titled “Twelve Hours with Tracy Letts.” The event will feature 12 hours of staged readings of the playwright’s work over the years, including “August: Osage County” and 1993's “Killer Joe.”</p><p>“It’s strange,” Letts said with a quick chuckle thinking about an all-day festival dedicated to his plays. “It's very gratifying to write anything as a playwright and find that it has any value or currency for an audience many years later. So whenever you find that any of these pieces still speak to people, it's great.”</p><p>Letts said when he wrote "Bug," both Coon and Smallwood were too young to portray the roles they have now. But as they breathe fresh life into the characters crafted three decades ago, new audiences are connecting to the story.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-930000" name="image-930000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f9c85af/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2e70ab3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/23d1d26/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Tracy Letts, left, and Carrie Coon attend the premiere of "A House of Dynamite" at Alice Tully Hall during the 63rd New York Film Festival on Sunday, Sept. 28, 2025, in New York. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/23d1d26/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/1180be3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/23d1d26/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3500x1964+0+215/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F4b%2F78%2Ff06e71de49d8b3fafa6ac35b5c58%2Fap25273697193731.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“Carrie brings a real Midwestern pragmatism,” Letts said.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Evan Agostini/Invision/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Carrie [Coon], as she's performing in the play, comes out every night, and she finds kids waiting at the stage door who are doing scenes from “Bug” in acting class, or they're doing it at their school right now,” Letts said. “That's just great. The fact that kids are finding something in this play that speaks to them and that they think is worth repeating.”</p><p>One of the common questions Letts has been asked during the run is about working with his wife. He shrugs that question off, noting they’ve always liked and respected each other and had an honest dialogue — whether good or bad — about their work. But Letts lights up when he speaks about the uniqueness his wife brings to the role.</p><p>“Carrie brings a real Midwestern pragmatism,” he said. “Carrie's just such a physical actor and a physical person. And the physical transformation that Agnes goes through over the course of the play, there's a feral quality that's really needed in order to do justice to the part. A low center of gravity. And Carrie really has that. She's just fearless.”</p>
entries.author: Mike Davis | WBEZ

entries.title: Chicago-area Asians were arrested in Midway Blitz. They kept quiet about it, for a while.
entries.summary: <p>There’s a common phrase in Urdu that Rabia Amin hates: "Log kya kahenge.”</p><p>The 27-year-old law clerk said it translates to “What will people say?”</p><p>When Amin’s father was picked up by federal immigration agents last September and detained for more than three months, it was a concern about “log kya kahenge” that led her family to tell loved ones a lie: that 63-year-old Asif Amin Cheema was sick.</p><p>“It honestly wasn't a hard thing to say because he has health issues,” Amin said, adding that Cheema suffers from diabetes, high blood pressure and vision problems.</p><p>As the family made calls to immigration officials and attorneys to get him released, while also trying to keep his sandwich shop afloat, they did not want to contend with any gossip in their community.</p><p>“When you’re dealing with so much, the last thing we need to worry about is having to defend our family name,” Amin said.</p><p>Besides, the family thought Cheema would be released soon. After all, he had applied for asylum and had no criminal record. So like many immigrants in the U.S., the Amin family never imagined Cheema would be picked up by federal immigration agents.</p><p>“We're hard working. We weren't criminals,” Amin said. “I came from a perspective that it could never happen to us.”</p><p>But then it did, just three minutes from his home in west suburban Addison.</p><p>“They just … saw that he was a brown man,” Amin said. “They arrest people and then ask questions later.”</p><p>The months that followed his arrest were harrowing. The family learned that Cheema had a removal order for a missed court date, something they say their former immigration lawyer did not tell them. And then, just as he was about to get deported, he collapsed at the airport and ended up in the hospital.</p><p>Fearing he might die, the Amin family decided to talk to news outlets.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2026/01/01/cheema-deportation-pakistan" >Humboldt Park restaurant owner is on his way to deportation flight to Pakistan, family says</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>On New Year’s Day, the family held a press conference. Cheema was deported to Pakistan that evening.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-960000" name="image-960000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2eacd8c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff7%2F2c%2Fcc64090b46688a869ee422aee9f3%2Fcheema-260102-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rabia Amin speaks to reporters during a press conference in Rosementhours before her father was set to be deported back to Pakistan on Thursday, Jan. 1, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>Lack of media coverage and a false sense of security</h3><p>Amin’s father is one of more than 140 Asians in Illinois arrested during the second Trump administration, according to a WBEZ analysis of data obtained by the Deportation Data Project through a public records request. That makes up about 4% of all immigration-related arrests in Illinois. The majority of Asians arrested were from three countries: India, China and Kyrgyzstan.</p><p>The numbers only include arrests through Oct. 15, 2025, before the peak of Operation Midway Blitz.</p><p>Nationally, more than 8,000 Asian immigrants have been arrested since Trump returned to office. There have been numerous examples across the country of Asians — including American citizens and those with legal status — being arrested as part of Trump’s mass deportation campaign: a <a class="Link" href="https://www.mprnews.org/story/2026/01/20/chongly-scott-thao-says-ice-removed-him-from-home-in-his-underwear-after-warrantless-search" target="_blank" ><u>U.S. citizen of Hmong descent</u></a> in Minnesota, <a class="Link" href="https://www.npr.org/2025/09/11/g-s1-88213/south-korean-hyundai-workers-immigration-raid-atlanta-airport" target="_blank" ><u>South Korean workers at a car plant</u></a>, a <a class="Link" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/immigration-officials-deport-chinese-man-6-year-old-son-rcna250315" target="_blank" ><u>6-year-old Chinese boy</u></a> and his father who were in asylum proceedings.</p><p>Locally, leaders at various organizations serving Asian populations told WBEZ that over the past year, Chicago- area Asians have been picked up at routine immigration check-ins, at airports returning from a trip abroad, in front of homes and schools, outside grocery stores, and in rideshare lots near O’Hare International Airport.</p><p>But there wasn’t much media coverage about these incidents — despite the fact that Asians are the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/data/2025/06/26/census-bureau-estimates-show-fast-growing-asian-population-in-metro-chicago" target="_blank" ><u>fastest growing racial demographic</u></a> in the region. And while the Asian diaspora in Chicago includes dozens of ethnicities, in their experience of the past year with immigration enforcement, some common themes have emerged: Stigma and a false sense of security have often kept families from speaking publicly about arrests and detentions. But advocates say keeping quiet results in a lack of awareness and organizing around immigration enforcement in Asian communities.</p><p>Grace Pai, executive director of Asian Americans Advancing Justice Chicago, said the lack of news coverage around Asians affected by Trump’s deportation campaign is in part because “media tends to be interested in the human story, and so when there are not families that are willing to speak up, it's harder to get that coverage.”</p><p>Pai said fear, language barriers, and past experiences of political oppression in their native countries all contribute to families’ reticence to speak not just with the media but even within their own communities.</p><p>She added that there is also shame and stigma, a “hyperawareness of that public judgment or perception, especially because so many immigrant communities are very tight-knit.”</p><p>Pai and other leaders from organizations serving Indian, Chinese, Filipino, and Korean populations told WBEZ that, at the beginning of the second Trump administration, there was also a false sense of security.</p><p>“Early on there was a lot of skepticism about Know Your Rights trainings and flyers, " said Vân Huynh, executive director of the Vietnamese Association of Illinois. “People were like, 'No, no, we're not worried about it.' ”</p><p>Anita Puri, who leads the Indo American Center, an organization that serves the South Asian community, agreed: “There was this belief that, ‘Oh, it won't happen to me, I'm fine — I have proper documentation, or I've never had criminal activity.’ ”</p><p>But things have begun to shift in many Chicago-area Asian communities. Groups say residents and business owners have begun requesting more Know Your Rights trainings and legal workshops. Puri said her organization has hired a second attorney to help with immigration cases.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Lisa Wright is the director of government affairs and advocacy at the Chinese American Service League. She says families are realizing there is a cost if they don’t speak up.<br></p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times<br></p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>‘It’s so important that we coalesce’</h3><p>Lisa Wright, director of government affairs and advocacy at the Chinese American Service League, says as videos and social media posts have spread through Asian communities, families are realizing the cost of not speaking up.</p><p>“You risk losing somebody you love, you risk access to information [and] access to resources that could really save your life or somebody's life,” said Wright, who is Taiwanese American and now carries a copy of her passport around.</p><p>She added that with the <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/immigration/2025/11/17/chicago-minority-groups-oppose-ice" target="_blank" ><u>potential return</u></a> of more federal immigration agents in the spring, it’s important for Asian organizations to band together to prepare for that next wave.</p><p>“Each ethnicity has an organization that represents them, and sometimes they can operate in their silos,” Wright said. “It's so important that we coalesce and build a coalition together.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7d2ee43/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4032x2263+0+381/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb8%2F53%2Fa53488794262afb0c70878067116%2Fimg-6225.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rabia Amin packs clothing to send to her father, who was deported back to Pakistan. He lost a lot of weight while he was in detention.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Esther Yoon-Ji Kang/WBEZ</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3>‘You don’t win by staying silent’</h3><h3></h3><p>Building coalitions and speaking out were top of mind for Rabia Amin on a rainy night in January, as she packed supplies like diabetes test strips and a blood pressure monitor for her dad. In a pile on the family’s dining table, there were also cans of shaving gel, glaucoma medication, and new clothes. Cheema had lost more than 30 pounds while in detention and needed a new wardrobe.</p><p>Amin’s sister would fly out the next morning to help her dad get situated in a country he had not lived in for three decades.</p><p>As she organized the supplies, Amin thought back to last September.</p><p>“We tried to play nice, we tried to play fair, we tried to keep it quiet,” she said. “But you don't win [by] staying silent, and I think it hurts you more than anything.”</p><p>She wants Asians to speak up and band together not just with one another, but with all immigrant communities who are being targeted.</p><p>“It hasn't even been a year since this administration has been [back] in office,” Amin said. “If this is the amount of damage they've done in one year, I can't even imagine what they're gonna do for the next three.”</p><p><i>Contributing: Amy Qin</i><br></p>

entries.title: Bad Bunny taps Chicago conductor for surprise Super Bowl halftime orchestra
entries.summary: <p>Eagle-eyed Chicago classical-music fans spotted a familiar face during Bad Bunny’s Sunday evening Super Bowl halftime show:<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2025/06/06/giancarlo-guerrero-grant-park-symphony-music-festival-conductor" target="_blank" ><u> Giancarlo Guerrero,</u></a> artistic director and principal conductor of the Grant Park Music Festival.</p><p>Guerrero was spotlighted among some 700 performers who took part in Bad Bunny’s sprawling performance, which included famed vocalists Ricky Martin and Lady Gaga as well as singers and musicians across a wide range of genres. </p><p>Guerrero, who was named to the Grant Park Music Festival post in 2024 and conducted his first concerts last summer, led a 30-member string orchestra composed of San Francisco-area musicians in the song “Monaco.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-570000" name="image-570000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f8ccf2f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F62%2Fdd%2Fbadfc5e04808a3e5f55f6c0d948c%2Fgiancarlo-05xx25-19.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Giancarlo Guerrero, the artistic director and principal conductor of the Grant Park Music Festival and Orchestra, poses for a portrait at the Pritzker Pavilion in May 2025. Guerrero led his first season for the popular summer festival last summer. </p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“It has been an absolutely unbelievable, unforgettable, life-changing experience all-around,” Guerrero told WBEZ/Chicago Sun-Times on Sunday night after just getting back to his hotel room. “To be part of it, honestly, is one of the greatest joys in my life and something that will stay with me forever.”</p><p>In what he called a “beautiful surprise,” Guerrero was invited to take part in the show just nine days before it took place. He rushed to San Francisco last Tuesday to begin rehearsals after signing a non-disclosure agreement that he would not discuss his participation ahead of time.</p><p>“It all came about very, very quickly. My manager got a call from Bad Bunny’s people saying that he had requested me to be part of the show. They wanted a prominent Latino conductor, and I immediately jumped at the idea,” said Guerrero, who was born in Nicaragua and grew up in Costa Rica.</p><p>The six-time Grammy Award-winning conductor was the first major classical music figure to take part in a Super Bowl halftime show since another noted maestro, Gustavo Dudamel, did so in 2016.</p><p>“The fact that he [Bad Bunny] wanted to include an actual string orchestra with an actual conductor tells you his musical interests go beyond what you would think: pop,” Guerrero said of the Puerto Rican rapper and singer. “I think it’s a great moment particularly for classical music, because normally it gets overlooked.”</p><p>The 10-week Grant Park festival takes place each summer in Millennium Park’s Pritzker Pavilion. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2026/01/06/grant-park-festival-chicago-classical-millennium-park-music-free-ben-folds" target="_blank" ><u>This year’s lineup</u></a> will feature a heavy dose of music from American composers, as the country marks its 250th birthday. The first concert is scheduled for June 10.</p><p>“What can I say about Benito [Antonio Martínez Ocasio], Bad Bunny. What a talent, what a musician,” Guerrero said. “I have to say this has been beyond my wildest dreams.”</p>

href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-t/" target="_blank" >Asians arrested in Midway Blitz and their families kept quiet about it — for a while</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-i/" target="_blank" >Esther Yoon-Ji Kang</a></h5><p><b>Communities impacted</b>: In Illinois, more than 140 Asians have been arrested during the second Trump administration, making up about 4% of immigration-related arrests in the state, according to a WBEZ analysis of data obtained by the Deportation Data Project through a public records request. The majority were from India, China and Kyrgyzstan. The numbers only include arrests through Oct. 15, 2025, before the peak of Operation Midway Blitz.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Local leaders at various organizations serving Asian populations told WBEZ that over the past year, Chicago-area Asians have been picked up at routine immigration check-ins, at airports returning from a trip abroad, in front of homes and schools, outside grocery stores, and in rideshare lots near O’Hare International Airport.</p><p><b>What experts say</b>: The leaders say there hasn't been much media coverage about these incidents, though Asians are the <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-d/" target="_blank" >fastest-growing racial demographic</a> in the region. While the diasporas in Chicago include dozens of ethnicities, leaders point to stigma and a false sense of security as common factors that have kept families quiet, contributing to an overall lack of awareness and organizing.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-h/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>MORE ON IMMIGRATION ✶</h4><div 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-203babf4-05bf-11f1-bcea-21aac85e3c9a"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-k/" target="_blank" ><b>Judge OKs evidence release</b></a>: A federal judge said Friday she’ll allow the release of text messages sent and received by the Border Patrol agent who shot Marimar Martinez last fall in Chicago. Martinez’s attorney said the texts and other evidence could be released as soon as Monday.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-u/" target="_blank" ><b>Unlawfully detained</b></a>: A federal judge in Indiana found that immigration authorities are unlawfully detaining the Chicago man acquitted last month of offering $10,000 for the murder of U.S. Border Patrol Cmdr. Gregory Bovino.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-o/" target="_blank" ><b>‘Wholly inappropriate’</b></a>: That's what Cook County State’s Attorney Eileen O’Neill Burke called Mayor Brandon Johnson’s executive order targeting federal immigration agents, telling her staff that the order could jeopardize criminal prosecutions.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-b/" target="_blank" ><b>DHS funding</b></a>: Sen. Dick Durbin said Democrats will continue to block U.S. Department of Homeland Security funding until Republicans agree to 10 reforms in the tactics of federal agents involved in President Donald Trump’s immigration operations. Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-yh/" target="_blank" >Why roundabouts are increasingly popping up in the suburbs</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-yk/" target="_blank" >Robert Herguth</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-yu/" target="_blank" >David Struett</a></h5><p><b>Round these parts</b>: Over the last few years, more roundabouts have been constructed in the suburbs. The Illinois Department of Transportation’s district covering state routes in Cook, DuPage, Kane, Lake, McHenry and Will counties now includes eight roundabouts on those roads. Eleven more are planned, and another dozen are being discussed, officials say. Downstate, there are two roundabouts, and the state agency expects to put in another eight. Elsewhere downstate, another 15 are anticipated. </p><p><b>Circular logic</b>: Experts consider roundabouts to be safer and more efficient, and have a longer service life, than traditional intersections with stop signs or stoplights. If they’re put in the right place with the right design, experts say they can slow down traffic and reduce carbon emissions and fuel consumption. They aren’t necessarily cheaper, though, and can require more pavement, land and design elements, experts say.</p><p><b>What about here?</b>: The Chicago Department of Transportation "has not constructed any modern roundabouts, and none are currently in the works or planned," a spokesperson said. There are numerous traffic circles in the city, though, usually built in consultation with local City Council members and not always liked by drivers.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-jl/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>LET’S HEAR FROM YOU 🗣️</h4><p>Should Chicago be like the suburbs and install roundabouts — or <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-jr/" target="_blank" >more traffic circles</a>? Armentrout</a></h5><p><b>Who's running</b>: Junaid Ahmed, Yasmeen Bankole, Melissa Bean, Sanjyot Dunung, Neil Khot, Kevin Morrison, Dan Tully and Ryan Vetticad are running for the Democratic nomination to replace U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi in the 8th Congressional District, which is anchored in the northwest suburbs.</p><p><b>Hot seat</b>: Krishnamoorthi is giving up the congressional seat he’s held for nearly a decade to seek retiring U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin’s seat. The winner of the Democratic primary will be favored in November’s general election over the winner of the Republican field, which includes Kevin Ake, Jennifer Davis, Herbert Hebein and Mark Rice.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Representatives vote on federal laws, advocate for their districts, and work to secure federal funding and other resources for constituents. Members of Congress vote on laws that affect all Americans.</p><p><b>Their backstories</b>: A tech entrepreneur who lost to Krishnamoorthi in 2022, a politician aiming to take back the seat she lost nearly 15 years ago, a tech service business owner — these are some of the candidates' backstories. class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-td/" target="_blank" >Joy fills Humboldt Park during ‘Benito Bowl’ watch party for Super Bowl halftime show</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-th/" target="_blank" >Cindy Hernandez</a></h5><p>Some fans were settling in to watch the Seattle Seahawks play the New England Patriots, but others were tuning in to see Puerto Rican superstar Bad Bunny take the Super Bowl stage for the halftime show.</p><p>Bad Bunny headlined Sunday’s performance, which some fans dubbed the "Benito Bowl." The 31-year-old, born Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, is the first Spanish-language solo artist to headline a halftime show alone.</p><p>In Humboldt Park, Chicago’s largest Puerto Rican neighborhood, organizers of the annual Fiestas Puertorriqueñas hosted a watch party at their VIP Residencia pop-up space, 2701 W. Division St.</p><p>The event drew dozens who cheered for the singer and sang along to his top hits throughout the 13-minute performance. Instead of wearing their favorite team’s jersey, partygoers wore Puerto Rican flags, Bad Bunny T-shirts and pavas, the traditional Puerto Rican straw hats.</p><p>Organizer Melissa Gomez said she wanted to create an event that would bring the community together, and Bad Bunny’s performance provided the perfect occasion to do just that.</p><p>Bad Bunny closed the show with a parade of flags from countries representing North, Central and South America, ending with the message, "Together, we are America."</p><p>"I’m feeling really so proud," said Evelyn Cato, 60, of Logan Square. "Despite all of the negativity, he’s brought communities together."</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-tk/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>DAILY QUESTION ☕️</h4><p><b>On Friday, we asked you</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-tu/" target="_blank" >How do you want to see $500,000 used to improve Chicago’s parks?</a></p><p>"Basic maintenance, including more trash [and] recycling barrels and more staff to empty them, and better trimming of bushes and trees. Repair and straighten park benches. Pothole patching on park drives, parking lots and walkways. [The money] won't build a new park, but it could sure improve the ones we already have." — <i>Roger Deschner</i></p><p>"I would love to see the city parks shift to native grasses that don't need to be mowed, instead of the typical lawn grass we see now. Much as I love that fresh-cut grass smell, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-il/" target="_blank" >low-mow lawns are better for the soil</a>, better for biodiversity, better at conserving water, and have more flowers. What could be more 'City in a Garden?'" — <i>Phoebe Murtagh</i></p><p>For more answers on this topic, listen to <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-ir/" target="_blank" >Friday’s broadcast of “Say More,”</a> where hosts Mary Dixon and Patrick Smith checked in with Chicago Park District head Carlos Ramirez-Rosa and took listener calls. 🎧</p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wyduiud-l-iy/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>
